review.title: A case study of algorithm selection for the traveling thief problem
review.abstract: Many real-world problems are composed of several interacting components. In order to facilitate research on such interactions, the Traveling Thief Problem (TTP) was created in 2013 as the combination of two well-understood combinatorial optimization problems.

sections.text: With this article, we contribute in four ways: First, we create a comprehensive dataset containing the performance data of 21 TTP algorithms based on the full original set of 9720 TTP instances; second, we define 55 features for all TPP instances that can be used to select the best algorithm per instance; third, we use these algorithms and features to create the initial algorithm portfolios for TTP that clearly outperform each best algorithm; and finally, we examine which algorithms contribute most to this portfolio.Keywords: combinatorial optimization, instance analysis, algorithm portfolio

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, most of them will be able to play by the rules that they have set themselves, and they will be able to play by the rules that they have set themselves.

sections.heading: 2 The travelling thief problem (TTP)
sections.text: The itinerant theft problem (TTP) [6] is a current attempt to create an abstraction of multi-component problems with component dependence. It combines two problems and creates a new problem with two components. In particular, it combines the itinerant seller problem (TSP) and the knapsack problem (KP), as both problems are known and have been studied in the field of optimization for many years. In this section, we motivate the TTP as an academic problem that closes an important gap in research and then formally defines it.

sections.heading: 2.1 Motivation
sections.text: In fact, most people who are able to move are able to move, to move and to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move and to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move and to move.

sections.heading: 2.2 Formal Definition
sections.text: We use the definition of the TTP of [41]. Given is a set of cities N = {1,.., n} and a set of positions M = {1,. −, m} distributed between cities. Each position that is positioned in the city i marks the distance between them. Each city i, except the first, contains a set of positions Mi = {1,.,., mi}, M =, n Wed. Each position that is positioned in the city i is marked by their profit spades and weight wik, i.e. the position Iik (pik, wik). The thief must visit all cities exactly once from the first city and return to it at the end. Any position can be selected in any city as long as the total weight of the collected positions does not exceed the specified capacity.

sections.heading: 2.3 Algorithms for TTP
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 3 Algorithm Selection
sections.text: As we will see in section 4, no algorithm dominates all other algorithms on all instances. One way to take advantage of this complementarity of algorithms is to select algorithms [16, 44] to select a powerful algorithm based on individual instances.

sections.heading: 3.1 Problem Statement
sections.text: The problem with algorithm selection is to find a mapping of problem cases to algorithms, which is done by calculating numerical features - so-called instance characteristics - that describe a problem instance, and then learning an mapping from the resulting attribute space to algorithms. Figure 2 shows the general workflow of algorithm selection. We will describe instance characteristics for the TTP later (in Section 5), but a simple feature is, for example, the number of cities. Based on these instance characteristics, we select an algorithm from a portfolio of 21 TTP algorithms that we have described in Section 4.2 to solve the instance at hand. The selection step is typically accomplished with machine learning. Based on collected training data (i.e. instance characteristics and performance data on training instances), we learn a machine learning model that maps from instance characteristics to a well-functioning algorithm.

sections.heading: 3.2 Popular Algorithm Selection Approaches
sections.text: One of the first successful algorithm selection procedures for satisfaction problems was SATzilla [49]. Two main concepts were used: (i) Learning an empirical performance model [19, 25] that predicts the performance of an algorithm for a particular instance, and (ii) the static algorithm scheme [15, 21, 49], which provides a sequence of algorithms with a respective runtime budget. SATzilla uses such a static scheme for "pre-compensation" to solve simple instances without the compression of features. Other approaches include classification models (e.g. ME-ASP by [28], and CSHC by, which directly assigns algorithms.

sections.heading: 4 Benchmarking of TTP Algorithms
sections.text: An important step in creating algorithm portfolios is to conduct experiments in which the performance of algorithms is determined on the basis of the available problem instances. To this end, in this section we present the originally defined set of TTP instances and outline the experimental setup and results.1http: / / challenge.icon-fet.eu /

sections.heading: 4.1 Introduction of Benchmark Instances
sections.text: For our investigations, we use the set of TTP instances defined by Polyakovskiy et al. [41].2 In these cases, the two components of the problem are so balanced that the approximate optimal solution of a partial problem does not dominate the optimal solution of another partial problem.2 The characteristics of the original 9,720 instances vary greatly. We outline the most important of these as follows: 3 • The instances have 51 to 85,900 cities, based on instances from the TSPlib of [43]; • For each TSP and KP combination, there are three different types of knapsack problems: uncorrelated, uncorrelated with similar weights, and strongly correlated types, where the last type is difficult for different types of knapsack solvers due to [29, 41]. • For each TSP and KP combination, there are three different types of knapsack problems: uncorrelated, uncorrelated with similar weights, and strongly correlated types, with 41 of the last type for different types of knapsack solvers].

sections.heading: 4.2 Benchmark Results
sections.text: In this context, it should be noted that this is not a purely formal solution, but a purely formal one.

sections.heading: 5 Instance Features for the TTP
sections.text: In total, we look at 55 TTP instance characteristics. Of these, 47 are characteristics from previous studies. Here, we look at the lowest, middle and middle edge costs, as well as the ratio of the edges to the distances where the distance is smaller than the mean distance, the proportion of distances where the distance is smaller. In this sense, the difference between the distances is greater than the mean distance, the proportion of different distances (i.e., the standard deviation of the distance), and we look at the mode frequency, quantity and mean. Finally, we use the expected tour length for a random tour multiplied by the sum of all edge costs.

sections.heading: 6 Experimental Study of Algorithm Selection

sections.heading: 8 Analysis of Feature Importance and Their Cal-
sections.text: This year is the highest in the history of the country.

sections.heading: 9 Concluding Remarks
sections.text: In this article, we presented the first study of algorithm portfolios for the TTP. First, we examined the performance of 21 existing TTP algorithms using the full original set of 9720 TTP instances created by Polyakovskiy et al. [41], and defined 55 instance characteristics for TTP. Then, we examined various approaches to the resulting algorithm selection problem, showing very significant improvements over the individual best algorithms and closing the gap between these and an omniscient oracle by 90%. Finally, we examined which algorithms contribute most to the portfolio and found that the algorithms with the best average performance (e.g. the complex C3-C6 and MATLS and the black intelligence approaches starting with M) were quite important for the portfolio due to their performance on small and medium-sized TTP instances. Interestingly, the relatively simple heuristic S5 will continue to utilize the overall TTP performance of all the other benchmarks, so we can perform well on the large instances of this TTP and thus the most important TTP algorithms of all.

referenceMentions.context: The academic traveling thief problem (TTP) [6] is quickly gaining attention as an NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem that combines two wellknown subproblems: the traveling salesperson problem (TSP) and the knapsack problem (KP).

The motivation for the TTP is to allow the systematic investigation of interactions between two hard component problems, to gain insights that eventually help solve real-world problems more efficiently [8].
To exploit this complementarity of existing algorithms, here we study the applicability of algorithm selection [44] to this problem.
• We analyze the performance of 21 TTP algorithms on the original set of 9720 instances created by Polyakovskiy, Bonyadi, Wagner, Michalewicz, and Neumann [41] (Section 4);
The traveling thief problem (TTP) [6] is a recent attempt to provide an abstraction of multicomponent problems with dependency among components.

For example, Weise, Zapf, Chiong, and Nebro [48] discussed premature convergence, ruggedness, causality, deceptiveness, neutrality, epistasis, and robustness, which make optimization problems hard to solve.
Michalewicz and Fogel [35] discussed a few different reasons behind the hardness of real-world problems, including problem size, presence of noise, multi-objectivity, and presence of constraints.
Most of these features have been captured in different optimization benchmark sets, such as TSPlib [43], MIPlib [22] and OR-library [2].

The second is the automatic algorithm selection method AutoFolio system [26].

AutoFolio uses the flexible FlexFolio framework [14], which combines several different algorithm selection methods, and searches for the best suited algorithm selection approach (and its hyperparameter settings) for a given algorithm selection scenario using algorithm configuration [17] via the model-based configurator SMAC [18].

AutoFolio uses the flexible FlexFolio framework [14], which combines several different algorithm selection methods, and searches for the best suited algorithm selection approach (and its hyperparameter settings) for a given algorithm selection scenario using algorithm configuration [17] via the model-based configurator SMAC [18].

As shown by [26], AutoFolio often chooses the pair-wise classification approach of SATzilla, but it is more robust than other algorithm selection approaches since it can also switch to other approaches if necessary.

As a result, AutoFolio established state-of-the-art performance on several different domains in the algorithm selection library [5] and performed best on two out of three tracks of the ICON challenge.

metadata.abstractText: Many real-world problems are composed of several interacting components. In order to facilitate research on such interactions, the Traveling Thief Problem (TTP) was created in 2013 as the combination of two wellunderstood combinatorial optimization problems. With this article, we contribute in four ways. First, we create a comprehensive dataset that comprises the performance data of 21 TTP algorithms on the full original set of 9720 TTP instances. Second, we define 55 characteristics for all TPP instances that can be used to select the best algorithm on a per-instance basis. Third, we use these algorithms and features to construct the first algorithm portfolios for TTP, clearly outperforming the single best algorithm. Finally, we study which algorithms contribute most to this portfolio.
